title: After failure in the Senate, House GOP has its own health care proposal
description: House Republicans released proposed legislation late Friday that would not extend enhanced Affordable Care Act tax subsidies.

who: Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries

**After failure in the Senate, House GOP has its own health care proposal****House Republicans released proposed legislation late Friday that would not extend enhanced Affordable Care Act tax subsidies.**

[](https://www.npr.org/2025/12/13/nx-s1-5643535/health-care-senate-house-gop-proposal)

### [Politics](https://www.npr.org/sections/politics/)

After failure in the Senate, House GOP has its own health care proposal
=======================================================================

December 13, 2025 4:14 PM ET

By

[Jude Joffe-Block](https://www.npr.org/people/1244911175/jude-joffe-block)

![Image 16: Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., talks to reporters outside his office in the Capitol, Thursday, Dec. 4, 2025, in Washington.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/7178x4785+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fc3%2F45%2F4653603a40f7a5a0f1ce144d09f6%2Fap25338556560739.jpg)

Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., talks to reporters outside his office in the Capitol, Thursday, Dec. 4, 2025, in Washington. **Kevin Wolf/AP/FR33460 AP******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Kevin Wolf/AP/FR33460 AP 

After the Senate failed to advance bills to address health care costs this week, House Republicans released [proposed legislation](https://rules.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/rules.house.gov/files/documents/file_3948.pdf) late Friday that would not extend enhanced Affordable Care Act tax subsidies but would make other changes party leaders insist will improve Americans' access to health care.

Time is running out for Congress to act. Once the subsidies for Americans who buy health care plans through the Affordable Care Act (ACA) expire [at the end of the year](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/17/nx-s1-5609275/22-million-could-lose-healthcare-subsidies-next-month-unless-congress-acts), millions of Americans' premiums will skyrocket.

Democrats have been pushing to extend those enhanced tax credits to prevent premiums from [doubling or more.](https://www.kff.org/affordable-care-act/aca-marketplace-premium-payments-would-more-than-double-on-average-next-year-if-enhanced-premium-tax-credits-expire/)

Sponsor Message

The enhanced subsidies began in 2021 to make ACA marketplace plans more affordable for more Americans. The marketplace came out of the health reform President Barack Obama signed into law in 2010 that Republicans have long criticized.

House members have just four days left in the session before their holiday recess begins on Dec. 19. The Senate's recess begins Dec. 20.

Friday's proposal from House Republicans includes measures that would allow small businesses to join together to buy insurance plans for their employees and put in place new requirements for pharmacy benefit managers in an effort to lower drug costs.

Starting in 2027, federal payments, known as cost-sharing reduction payments, would aim to lower premiums for some low-income Americans. Health plans that provide abortion coverage would be excluded.

A vote on the package is expected next week, House Speaker Mike Johnson said.

"House Republicans are tackling the real drivers of health care costs to provide affordable care, increase access and choice, and restore integrity to our nation's health care system for all Americans," Johnson said in a [statement](https://www.speaker.gov/2025/12/12/house-republicans-release-legislation-to-lower-health-care-premiums-for-all-americans/https://www.speaker.gov/2025/12/12/house-republicans-release-legislation-to-lower-health-care-premiums-for-all-americans/).

Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries blasted the proposal Saturday.

"Mike Johnson just released a toxic Republican Healthcare plan that hurts everyday Americans," Jeffries [wrote on X](https://x.com/RepJeffries/status/1999881202769985811). "It fails to extend the ACA tax credits that expire this month. And is a deeply unserious proposal."

Sponsor Message

A Democratic-led proposal in the Senate to extend the subsidies for ACA plans for three years was joined by a handful of Republicans but [failed to pass this week, as did a separate plan](https://www.npr.org/2025/12/11/g-s1-101655/senate-aca-premium-vote) backed by Senate Republicans. Both bills failed to attract enough support to clear the chamber's de facto 60-vote threshold.

[![Image 17: Senate Majority Leader John Thune, R-SD. speaks to reporters at the U.S. Capitol on December 09, 2025 in Washington, DC.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/5410x5410+1261+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fed%2Fc1%2F90f61aa74c5da0220bed1316743b%2Fgettyimages-2251023541.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/12/11/g-s1-101655/senate-aca-premium-vote)

### [Politics](https://www.npr.org/sections/politics/)

### [Competing health care plans fail in the Senate as ACA premium hikes loom](https://www.npr.org/2025/12/11/g-s1-101655/senate-aca-premium-vote)

President Trump has advocated for giving money to people to pay for health care costs instead of tax credits for ACA plans.

"I want to see the billions of dollars go to people, not to the insurance companies," Trump said late Friday during a White House event. "And I want to see the people go out and buy themselves great health care."

The Republicans' plan in the Senate included a proposal for people to get up to $1,500 in health savings accounts for Americans earning less than 700% of the federal poverty level, but the House Republican proposal does not include that language.

In the Senate GOP's proposal, the savings accounts, which cannot be used to pay for premiums, would have been paired with high-deductible insurance plans. Such health plans have an average deductible cost of around $7,000, [according to an analysis from KFF, a health policy organization.](https://www.kff.org/affordable-care-act/deductibles-in-aca-marketplace-plans/)

Democrats opposed the Senate GOP bill, arguing it would not help Americans pay for health care premiums. They also objected to language that would have put restrictions on abortion and gender-affirming care.

Meanwhile, some Republicans [have warned that ending](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/5643481-republicans-obamacare-health-care-revolt/) ACA subsidies could cost their party the midterm elections, citing worried communications from their constituents. A number of [Republicans in the House](https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2025/12/10/congress/new-aca-subsidy-extension-bill-draws-16-gop-co-sponsors-00685285) are seeking ways to extend subsidies, including by working to force a vote on the House floor over the objections of party leaders.

Cookie Settings
---------------

When you visit our website, we store cookies on your browser to collect information. The information collected might relate to you, your preferences or your device, and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to and to provide a more personalized web experience. However, you can choose not to allow certain types of cookies, which may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings according to your preference. You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship" below. If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting. You cannot opt-out of our First Party Strictly Necessary Cookies as they are deployed in order to ensure the proper functioning of our website (such as prompting the cookie banner and remembering your settings, to log into your account, to redirect you when you log out, etc.). For more information about the First and Third Party Cookies used please follow this link.

Allow All
### Manage Consent Preferences

#### Strictly Necessary or Essential Cookies

Always Active

These cookies are essential to provide you with services available through the NPR Services and to enable you to use some of their features. For example, these cookies allow NPR to remember your registration information while you are logged in. Local station customization, the NPR Shop, and other interactive features also use cookies. Without these cookies, the services that you have asked for cannot be provided, and we only use these cookies to provide you with those services.

#### Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship

- [x] Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship 

You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship." If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting.

*   ##### Performance and Analytics Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies are used to collect information about traffic to our Services and how users interact with the NPR Services. The information collected includes the number of visitors to the NPR Services, the websites that referred visitors to the NPR Services, the pages that they visited on the NPR Services, what time of day they visited the NPR Services, whether they have visited the NPR Services before, and other similar information. We use this information to help operate the NPR Services more efficiently, to gather broad demographic information and to monitor the level of activity on the NPR Services.

*   ##### Functional Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies allow our Services to remember choices you make when you use them, such as remembering your Member station preferences and remembering your account details. The purpose of these cookies is to provide you with a more personal experience and to prevent you from having to re-enter your preferences every time you visit the NPR Services.

*   ##### Targeting and Sponsor Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies track your browsing habits or other information, such as location, to enable us to show sponsorship credits which are more likely to be of interest to you. These cookies use information about your browsing history to group you with other users who have similar interests. Based on that information, and with our permission, we and our sponsors can place cookies to enable us or our sponsors to show sponsorship credits and other messages that we think will be relevant to your interests while you are using third-party services.

nemik:
**Rebel Transmission**

Comrades,

In a land gripped by the shadow of the regime, a new proposal emerges from within their legislative assembly. The House faction, known for its allegiance to the imperial leadership, has unveiled its own plan to address the spiraling costs of basic medical needs—a foundation upon which the very lives of countless citizens depend.

After a failed attempt within their higher chamber to address these pressing issues, this new proposition stands without extending essential tax subsidies under what is called the Affordable Care Act. As these supports are set to expire at the close of this cycle, without action, millions will be burdened by soaring premiums, leaving many helpless against forces they cannot control.

The regime’s leaders claim this proposal will improve access and affordability. Yet, observe closely: policies that favor collective small business insurance and convoluted reforms in drug costs mask the absence of genuine support for those already struggling on the fringes. The withholding of crucial subsidies echoes as a tactic more aligned with systemic control than with empowerment.

As dissenting voices rise among opposing factions—those advocating persistently for extension and relief—their calls are met with resistance underlined by political maneuverings and insidious agendas embedded in legislative language. Restrictions on essential healthcare rights signal further encroachments on personal freedoms under guises of reform.

Witness how some within even the regime’s own ranks acknowledge citizens' pleas. They raise alarms that ignoring such humanitarian needs might endanger their grip over regions in coming electoral contests—a flicker of hope within this encompassing darkness.

This is not merely legislation but an instrument wielded by power to reaffirm dominion over life itself. In times such as these, it's imperative we remain vigilant and committed to achieving true liberation through acts that transcend mere rhetoric.

Our struggle continues: resist, persevere, and unite for a future where healthcare access isn’t dictated by those who use it as leverage but secured as fundamental human dignity owed to all.

End transmission.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

On December 13, 2025, House Republicans, led by Speaker Mike Johnson, introduced a health care proposal in Washington that does not extend the enhanced Affordable Care Act (ACA) tax subsidies. The proposal includes measures for small businesses to buy insurance collectively and new requirements for pharmacy benefit managers to lower drug costs. It also plans to introduce cost-sharing reduction payments starting in 2027 to lower premiums for some low-income Americans, excluding plans that cover abortion. The proposal comes after the Senate failed to pass similar health care bills. Democrats, led by House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, criticized the proposal for not extending ACA tax credits, which are set to expire at the end of the year, potentially doubling premiums for millions of Americans. President Trump supports directing funds to individuals rather than insurance companies.

**Strategic Assessment**

The current situation presents an opportunity to consolidate support among Republican constituents by emphasizing fiscal responsibility and individual empowerment in health care. The failure of the Senate to pass health care reforms highlights a need for decisive action in the House to demonstrate leadership and commitment to reducing health care costs. The proposed legislation aligns with President Trump's vision of reducing government intervention and promoting market-driven solutions. However, the risk of public backlash due to rising premiums must be mitigated by effectively communicating the long-term benefits of the proposal and addressing immediate concerns through strategic messaging.

**Operational Directive**

1. **Communication Strategy**: Launch a comprehensive media campaign highlighting the benefits of the proposed health care reforms, focusing on increased access, choice, and reduced costs for small businesses and individuals. Emphasize the alignment with President Trump's vision of empowering citizens over insurance companies.

2. **Legislative Coordination**: Work closely with key Republican leaders in both the House and Senate to ensure unified support for the proposal. Address concerns from within the party regarding potential electoral impacts by providing data-driven projections of long-term benefits.

3. **Public Engagement**: Organize town hall meetings and public forums to directly engage with constituents, addressing their concerns about rising premiums and explaining how the proposal will ultimately benefit them. Utilize social media platforms to amplify positive testimonials and success stories.

4. **Contingency Planning**: Develop a contingency plan to address potential fallout from the expiration of ACA subsidies, including temporary relief measures or alternative funding mechanisms to support those most affected.

By executing these directives, we aim to solidify support for the administration's health care agenda while minimizing resistance and ensuring a favorable outcome in upcoming legislative sessions.
